title: Half a million BA customers given go-ahead to sue airline over data breach
text:
Half a million BA customers have been given go-ahead to sue the airline after a data breach (Picture: Getty)

Half a million British Airways (BA) customers have been given the green light to take the airline to court after their personal details were compromised in a cyber attack.

After BA’s systems were targeted, information including payment details and addresses were exposed to the attackers.

On Friday, Mr Justice Warby gave the go ahead for the mass legal action.

The scam saw the passengers diverted to a fake website where their details were harvested.

When BA discovered the breach last September, it informed the Information Commissioners Office (ICO) and contacted affected customers.

More than 5,000 affected customers are currently being represented by SPG Law while another 230 are being represented by Your Lawyers Limited.

In total around 500,000 people have been affected.

The breach happened after BA’s systems were targeted in a cyber attack

(Picture: Witthaya Prasongsin / EyeEm)

The number of claimants could skyrocket after Mr Justice Warby ruled other potential victims of the attack had a 15 month window to join the group legal action.

BA is already facing a fine of more than £183 million over the breach, which started in June 2018.

An ICO spokesman said the fine is the largest it has handed out since the General Data Protection Regulation came into force last year.

The ICO said BA comprised a variety of information including log in and payment card details with ‘poor security arrangements’.

Information Commissioner Elizabeth Denham said she hoped the court ruling sent a message to others to take care of customers’ personal information.

She commented: ‘When you are entrusted with personal data you must look after it.

‘Those that don’t will face scrutiny from my office to check they have taken appropriate steps to protect fundamental privacy rights.’

British Airways is already facing a record fine over the breach

(Picture: Getty Images)

Alex Cruz, British Airways’ chairman and chief executive, said the airline was disappointed at the outcome of the investigation.

He added: ‘We have found no evidence of fraud/fraudulent activity on accounts linked to the theft.

‘We apologise to our customers for any inconvenience this event caused.’
